question_text: Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to which type of peripheral neuropathy?

options.A: Sensory neuropathy

question_text: Distal acquired demyelinating symmetric neuropathy (DADS) is characterized by which of the following?

options.A: Proximal weakness
options.B: Sensory deficits more than motor deficits

options.A: Measures nerve conduction velocity
options.B: Records electrical activity of muscles at rest and during contraction
options.C: Is primarily used to assess brain activity

question_text: An anti-MuSK patient who developed hepatotoxicity with azathioprine, what medication should be given?

options.A: Rituximab
40-year-old male patient presents with left arm weakness, thenar and hypothenar atrophy, fasciculations, and normal sensory examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
patient has a fracture in the acetabulum and notices numbness on the dorsum of the foot with weak dorsiflexion. Where is the lesion likely located?

question_text: In congenital myasthenic syndromes, what is the gene defect that causes worsening of symptoms with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors?

options.A: DOK7

patient presents with left wrist drop and has a history of right wrist drop that improved, as well as a right foot drop. She has a positive family history of similar presentations. Which of the following genes is expected to be found?
male patient with diabetes who is on metformin and has multiple comorbidities developed anemia with high MCV and neuropathy. What is the mechanism of developing this neuropathy?
patient who underwent bariatric surgery developed weakness and large fiber neuropathy, with normal B12 and methylmalonic acid levels. What is the likely deficiency?
patient presents with channelopathy. What is the best workup?

question_text: What is the effect of oral potassium in the management of Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis?

options.A: Prevents attack
patient develops myotonia after repetitive exercise and subsequently experiences weakness. There is a positive family history. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: What is a common presenting feature of Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN)?

options.A: Upper motor neuron signs

25-year-old male complains of a 14-month history of left-hand weakness. The weakness was progressive for 5 months and then became static. On examination, the affected hand muscles show intact elbow flexion and shoulder abduction, with sensory function intact. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: Congenital myasthenia gravis with distal and proximal weakness, facial involvement worsened with acetylcholinesterase inhibitor?

options.A: DOK7

question_text: In a scenario typical for paramyotonia congenita, what is the gene involved?

options.A: Sodium channel (SCN4A)

patient with dysferlinopathy presents with a CK level elevated 35 times the normal and mild upper limb weakness, mainly in the lower limbs, with significant calf atrophy and weak dorsiflexion. What is the likely diagnosis?

young boy went for a football match with his friends. Later, he started to have proximal muscle weakness, and his urine turned brown. He had a history of similar symptoms during his previous admission. What is the defective enzyme?

question_text: An infant presents with respiratory issues, electrical myotonia, and macroglossia. What is the likely diagnosis?

options.A: Pompe

young man who had abdominal pain around 1 week back and had a flu vaccine recently presented with a 5-day history of progressive distal dysesthesias and facial hyperhidrosis. Later on, he was tripping while walking and had weakness with decreased DTR on examination. What is the diagnosis?

patient with symptoms suggestive of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) was not responding to intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and was found to have positive neurofascin 155 antibodies. What is the treatment for this patient?
young lady post-vaginal hysterectomy presents with weakness in hip adductors and hip flexion. Which nerve is likely affected?

question_text: In a Guillain-Barré syndrome scenario, what is the predicting factor for intubation?

options.A: Presence of dysautonomia

question_text: In a scenario of AIDP, what are the early findings in NCS?

options.A: Prolonged or absent F wave with absent H Reflex
options.B: Increased conduction velocity with normal F wave latency
options.C: Normal sensory nerve action potentials with reduced motor amplitudes
options.D: Decreased distal motor latency with normal F wave
